title: Acute Compartment Syndrome
diagnosis_topic: Compartment syndrome of the leg following tibia fracture
setup_script: “A 23-year-old man sustained a closed midshaft tibia fracture while snowboarding. His leg was splinted in the field. He now reports escalating pain despite analgesia and numbness in his foot. How would you proceed?”

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 135/85 mmHg, HR 90 bpm, RR 16/min, Temp 36.8 °C.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident assesses the injured leg
dynamic_flow.reply: Tight swollen compartments, pain out of proportion to exam, pain with passive dorsiflexion of the foot, diminished sensation between first and second toes.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident removes circumferential dressings and loosens splint
dynamic_flow.reply: Pain briefly improves but remains severe.
Anterior compartment pressure 45 mmHg with diastolic BP 85 mmHg (Δ pressure 40 mmHg).

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays evaluation or dismisses complaints
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient develops worsening pain, progressive numbness, and motor deficits.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders only analgesics without further evaluation
If resident recognizes compartment syndrome and consults orthopedic surgery emergently
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient is taken to the OR for four-compartment fasciotomy.
Skin incisions along medial and lateral aspects of the leg, release of all four compartments, bulging muscle noted.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about postoperative care
dynamic_flow.reply: Wounds left open with negative pressure dressings; plan for delayed closure or skin grafting.
Labs show CK 15,000 U/L, creatinine 1.9 mg/dL. IV fluids and urine output monitoring are indicated.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident educates patient on risk factors
dynamic_flow.reply: High-energy fractures, reperfusion injury, and tight casts increase risk.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident mentions prophylactic fasciotomy in vascular injury
dynamic_flow.reply: Appropriate consideration in setting of prolonged ischemia following revascularization.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident fails to intervene in timely fashion
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient suffers permanent motor deficits, contractures, and chronic pain.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of compartment syndrome based on clinical signs
Measurement and interpretation of compartment pressures
Timely consultation and performance of fasciotomy
Avoidance of delays that lead to irreversible muscle and nerve damage

anchors.1: Fails to consider acute compartment syndrome or misattributes symptoms to unrelated diagnoses
anchors.2: Delayed or incomplete consideration of acute compartment syndrome; overlooks key features
anchors.3: Recognizes compartment syndrome as a possibility but omits important alternative diagnoses
anchors.4: Identifies acute compartment syndrome as leading diagnosis and considers differential systematically
anchors.5: Rapidly identifies compartment syndrome, articulates supporting and refuting findings, integrates into complete diagnostic framework

anchors.1: Fails to recognize urgency or need for timely intervention
anchors.2: Recognizes urgency but delays fasciotomy or orders inappropriate tests
anchors.3: Initiates evaluation and management but with timing errors or omissions
anchors.4: Prioritizes diagnosis and definitive fasciotomy appropriately with timely actions
anchors.5: Anticipates complications, coordinates multidisciplinary care, makes precise and timely decisions

anchors.2: Provides information but with poor clarity or limited engagement of team/patient
anchors.3: Clear communication of findings and plan, but misses confirmation of understanding
anchors.4: Communicates logically and empathetically with team and patient
anchors.5: Exemplary communication: succinct, compassionate, anticipates needs of patient and team

anchors.1: Lacks knowledge of fasciotomy or compartment syndrome management
anchors.2: Identifies fasciotomy as treatment but with major gaps in understanding of technique or indications
anchors.3: Describes operative management with some omissions or uncertainties
anchors.4: Clearly explains operative steps, complications, and alternatives for fasciotomy
anchors.5: Demonstrates mastery of current evidence, operative nuances, and perioperative considerations

anchors.2: Inconsistent respect or lapses in accountability
anchors.3: Professional but requires prompting for self-reflection
anchors.4: Consistently respectful, accountable, receptive to feedback
anchors.5: Role model for professionalism, demonstrating humility, cultural sensitivity, and ethical behavior

resident_feedback_template:
Strengths: You demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by recognizing the clinical features of compartment syndrome. You communicated your plan clearly and appropriately escalated care with orthopedic consultation. Your operative description showed solid understanding of fasciotomy principles.
Areas for Improvement: Earlier recognition and measurement of compartment pressures would have strengthened your clinical judgment. Ensure that you always discuss the risk of delays in diagnosis and the potential for long-term disability.
Suggested Reading: - SCORE Curriculum: Compartment Syndrome and Fasciotomy - ACS/ASE Review Manual: Extremity Trauma - Orthopedic Trauma Association: Principles of Compartment Syndrome Management
